text: You're Barack Obama. 4 years into your retirement, you awake to find a letter with no return address on your bedside table. It reads "I hope you've had a chance to relax Barack...but pack your bags and call the number below. It's time to start the real job." Signed simply, "JFK."

Obama spent the next minutes pondering his next course of action. He knew that he was not safe in his current place of residence, and he had made no plans for another place to go. The email showed a certain urgency to it, so Obama read it immediately. Obama was shocked to learn that Ben wrote that he was soon to be in danger, and that he needed to be moved to a safe house. Ben also wrote in his email urging Obama to do the same. The email never disclosed the reason for this warning, but Obama knew that something serious must be going on to make Ben so nervous.

Obama spent the next minutes pondering his next course of action. He knew that he was not safe in his current place of residence, and he had made no plans for another place to go. He then remembered there was a nearby presidential safe house that was to be used for such emergencies only, but he had not used it while during his presidency. Grabbing some essential items, he then left the house and went to the safe house. Not wanting to scare his family and friends nor place them in any danger, he didn't inform anyone that he was going into hiding for the time being.

After arriving at the safe house, Obama settled in and began to watch the news and social media in order to get a better idea of what was going on. He could not find anything that suggested his life was in danger, and he began to ponder if he was being too paranoid. It was a possibility he thought, that he wasn't in danger, and that Ben was simply wrong that their lives were in danger. But something inside him told him that Ben was right, and so he settled in for a long time. After a while, he received a text from an unmarked number. The text simply read to "Sit tight for now; you're fine."

Wondering if it was from Ben, Obama felt a bit more relieved that he made the right choice. In the safe house, he was safe from any danger that currently threatened his life, even if he didn't know what that may be. The safe house was well stocked on basic necessities, so he didn't have to worry about food or water for the next days, but he still wondered when it would be safe to exit the safe house. Five days later he would get a more definitive answer on what was going on, as the news reported that certain US politicians were being targeted and killed. Realizing his friend was right, and that he was potentially a target, he felt relieved he had chosen to hide out at the safe house. 

After a few days, the news reports began to calm down, and it seemed that things were going back to normal.
